title: Separable Diff Eq - Taylor Poly-Euler-Int by Parts

content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

Let <math alttext="y equals f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to x, equals y times, open parenthesis, x times the natural log of x, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo largeop="true">⋅</mo></mrow></mstyle><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.10em"></mspace><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="f of 1 equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. It can be shown that <math alttext="f double prime of 1, equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Write the second-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="x equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the Taylor polynomial to approximate <math alttext="f of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

Let <math alttext="y equals f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to x, equals y times, open parenthesis, x times the natural log of x, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo largeop="true">⋅</mo></mrow></mstyle><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.10em"></mspace><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="f of 1 equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. It can be shown that <math alttext="f double prime of 1, equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Write the second-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="x equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the Taylor polynomial to approximate <math alttext="f of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Use Euler’s method, starting at <math alttext="x equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with two steps of equal size, to approximate <math alttext="f of 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(c) Find the particular solution <math alttext="y equals f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to x, equals y times, open parenthesis, x times the natural log of x, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo largeop="true">⋅</mo></mrow></mstyle><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.10em"></mspace><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="f of 1 equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 7.5: (BC ONLY) Approximating Solutions Using Euler's Method

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
